baseline_groups.claim_summary: Municipalities aligned with the ruling party receive more government transfers to politically congruent (aligned) nonprofit organizations, measured via sharp RD at the election cutoff.
baseline_groups.notes: RD estimate: 1.39 euros per capita (SE=0.35, p<0.001). Linear polynomial, triangular kernel, MSE-optimal bandwidth (~16.2pp). Primary outcome of the paper.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Transfers to moderate (neither congruent nor non-congruent) organizations show no discontinuity at the electoral cutoff, supporting the interpretation that favoritism is targeted.
baseline_groups.notes: RD estimate: -0.06 (SE=0.15, p=0.68). Null result expected and found.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Transfers to non-congruent (opposition-aligned) organizations show no discontinuity at the cutoff.
baseline_groups.notes: RD estimate: -0.15 (SE=0.19, p=0.42). Null result expected and found.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Total transfers per capita also show a positive discontinuity, but smaller than the congruent-specific effect.
baseline_groups.notes: RD estimate: 1.08 (SE=0.48, p=0.023). Significant at 5% but not 1%.

global_notes: Paper: 'Organized Voters' by Camille Urvoy (AER 2025). Sharp RD design using French municipal elections. The running variable (alignm) is the win margin of the ruling party candidate. Many specifications apply the same spec_id to 4 different outcomes (congr1_3, congr2_3, congr3_3, total), so unique IDs are constructed as spec_id__outcome_var. The primary claim is about congruent organizations (G1); null results for moderate/non-congruent orgs support the specificity of the finding. Specs with different cutoffs (placebo) test RD validity. Heterogeneity specs test where the effect is concentrated.
